text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The coalition National Convention Assembly of churches, opposition parties, and civil society call for pro-reform rallies across Kenya on July 7. A similar rally in Nairobi on July 7, 1990 turned violent and at least 20 people were killed as a campaign for a switch to pluralist politics gathered pace.

- The High Court awards 10 million Kenyan shillings to presidential aide Joshuah Kulei after finding that The People newspaper owned by opposition leader Kenneth Matiba defamed him. Award is highest-ever for demafation in Kenya's history.

- Opposition FORD-Asili chairman Kenneth Matiba's decision not to register as a voter -- effectively barring himself from contesting parliamentary and presidential elections later this year -- receives mixed reactions from rank and file of party.
- Attempts by seven (opposition) parliament members to have President Daniel arap Moi censured for commenting on a matter before the courts fails after judge declines any comments.
- Confusion and panic grips FORD-Asili supporters countrywide after Matiba announces decision not to register as a voter. Declaration will end his parliamentary career.
- Kenya Revenue Authority, government's tax collecting agency, says it is owed 25 billion shillings by parastatals.

- Nairobi Stock Exchange (NSE) Chairman Jimnah Mbaru expects over one million investors on the Kenyan bourse after completion of a nationwide awareness campaign launched by authorities this year. Campaign has taken bourse officials to the provinces where they hope to convince ruralfolk to invest on the NSE.
- Britain will not take sides in Kenya's impending general election, Minister of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Tony Lloyd says during visit to Kenyan capital.

- Members of the Nairobi Christian Church question monthly salary of 198,000 Kenyan shillings paid to their Nigerian-born Pastor Richard Alawaye. Pastor rejects allegation and says his pay comes from Boston-based International Church of Christ.(Average Kenyan middle class workers earn average monthly salary of 25,000 shillings).
